critique: The most likely diagnosis in this patient with pancytopenia is myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) (Option B). MDS is a group of clonal stem cell disorders with ineffective hematopoiesis leading to peripheral blood cytopenias and dysplastic, hypercellular bone marrow. Most MDS cases are idiopathic and often age related, although chemical exposure (e.g., benzene) or chemotherapy or radiation therapy can cause secondary MDS. It is usually diagnosed in the seventh or eighth decades of life. Macrocytic anemia is the most common cytopenia observed in patients with MDS, but all cell lines can be affected. The peripheral blood smear often shows dysplastic cells, including hypogranular or hypolobular neutrophils and platelets. Bone marrow biopsy is required for diagnosis. This patient has pancytopenia with macrocytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and leukopenia accompanied by dysplastic, hypolobated neutrophils. These findings are all consistent with the diagnosis of MDS.Clonal hematopoiesis of indeterminate potential (CHIP) (Option A) describes detection of somatic clonal variants in genes often altered in hematologic malignancies (e.g., DNMT3A, TET2, ASXL1) in the absence of a known hematologic malignancy or other clonal disorder. Patients with CHIP do not have cytopenias, although they may develop MDS or acute myeloid leukemia over time. The risk of cardiovascular disease is also increased. This patient's macrocytic anemia and pancytopenia exclude the diagnosis of CHIP.Pure red cell aplasia (PRCA) (Option C) is characterized by normocytic or macrocytic anemia with decreased reticulocytes and absent or decreased erythrocyte precursors in the bone marrow. PRCA is not typically associated with dysplastic features of maturation or other cytopenias and is an unlikely diagnosis in this patient.Although most cases of MDS are idiopathic, secondary MDS can result from chemotherapy or radiation or chemical exposure (benzene). However, tiotropium is not associated with MDS or hematopoietic cell dysplasia, making tiotropium toxicity (Option D) an unlikely diagnosis.Cobalamin (vitamin B12) deficiency (Option E) can cause ineffective hematopoiesis, and patients may present with pancytopenia, usually with macrocytic anemia. However, vitamin B12 deficiency is classically associated with hypersegmented neutrophils rather than the dysplastic hypolobular neutrophils seen in this patient. MDS is a more likely diagnosis than vitamin B12 deficiency, although serum vitamin B12 levels should still be assessed.
key_points: Myelodysplastic syndromes are clonal stem cell disorders with ineffective hematopoiesis; macrocytic anemia is the most common cytopenia observed, but pancytopenia with evidence of dysplasia, including hypogranular or hypolobular neutrophils and platelets, may occur.
Bone marrow biopsy is necessary to diagnose myelodysplastic syndrome.
